column5: Newcomers encouraged to ‘make a difference’... https://t.co/mA5AwFvFkn I am so very proud of my alma mater and how vastly it has transformed since I was a newcomer. YES, the role of Stellenbosch University, and those privileged/lucky enough to study there, is to make a difference

Such a pleasure and privilege to be part of the Reseach Methods for Social-Ecological Systems Handbook’s website https://t.co/Scwsyaj2ws launch at @CST_SU Do check it out - superb resource and links to the open access handbook.

@MaikeHamann @sabbychesterman Such a pleasure and privilege to work on this. Congratulations team @MaikeHamann!  Do check out the publication. It’s excellent, especially the bridge from futuring (options) to recommendations (actions).

“Whichever nation ‘wins’ is the one who avoids self-inflicted wounds and makes capitalism work for the common good rather than for a small sliver of super-elites.” https://t.co/d4NV914DLZ via @NoemaMag
Do yourself a favour and get a flavour of some of the science happening on the African continent by checking out the CERI & Krisp newsletter. Link 👇

Long-ish read; fascinating story. Also illustrates that science is not a linear process.
It may have taken some time,but there are consequences. Will the reputational damage matter I wonder… cc @nextwavefutures
Looking forward to sharing a platform today with @WandileSihlobo at the @Hortgro symposium. South Africa agriculture, and deciduous fruit futures.

Two great articles on the @Hortgro site. One about our strategic foresight work https://t.co/ZnSk6zbojc and the other about the future of the South African deciduous fruit industry https://t.co/YyC7bc1cFS Our team relished working with this important sector and its stakeholders.

So very pleased that the @StellenboschUni UNESCO Chair in Complex Systems and Transformative African Futures is now official and announced. Looking forward to some amazing work with @Rikatier @CST_SU https://t.co/ghAioSeSr3
@AndrewDessler Not exactly a climate change scenario, but probably useful to add ‘The Limits to Growth’ and its subsequent updates and validation to the list https://t.co/8SPVWJlHUr

Now this is good news. A new centre for drug discovery in Africa. University of Cape Town’s Holistic Drug Discovery and Development (H3D) Centre with @JNJNews to address antimicrobial resistance — one of those ‘predictable surprises’ cc @Tuliodna  https://t.co/o2ILeouzAX
ICYMI: The really useful collection of articles in @voxdotcom about pandemic proofing: “The upgrades we can make today to fight the pandemics of tomorrow.” https://t.co/hDN12dmy6I

Watching CNN coverage of floods in KwaZulu-Natal @ZainAsher questions whether infrastructure - roads, bridges - are up to scratch in SA. Don’t seem to remember this question being asked during devastating, infrastructure busting floods in Vancouver earlier this year…

The superb ‘Vaxi Taxi’ initiative uses social infrastructure and public space instead of physical infrastructure to bring services to those who need them most by maximising material and social resources already available https://t.co/LXs5aBidKe

“The [Covid] responses that arguably mattered most did not happen at the level of grand policy, but at the level of eye-to-eye vision, compassion and care – not in boardrooms, but in living rooms, kitchens and streets. This is where we live …”

“The ways in which people came together during the pandemic highlighted the everyday miracles of living in SA. These are as much a part of our heritage as our violent history & painful inequality. Again & again, we find the best in ourselves and share it openly with one another.”

“Usually, the gap between designing a study and scaling it up to reach people on the ground takes years. Sisonke [vaccinating SA’s health care workers] did it in a matter of 17 days – and rewrote history.” They share their learnings 👇

Covid lockdowns mess with timing, so it feels like yesterday that we crossed this border by boat, parallel to the ferry https://t.co/OFICHQidKK   What a beautiful bridge, though. Hope the wildlife there is resilient. #KazangulaBridge

If you can spare the ~40min to watch this (link below) discussion on genomics surveillance and where to next wrt to COVID-19, please do. It is excellent - some top-of-range scientists share their learnings. SA’s own @Tuliodna is superb, and the work conducted here is remarkable.

Fascinating talk on 19 May at 18:00 CAT. “Developing a COVID-19 risk prediction platform using sewage water.” In SA a network of 60+ researchers from 26 institutions are working to establish a wastewater-based surveillance system. https://t.co/e3WAoBcoDl

Do consider attending the @SAIIA_info webinar on Building Anticipatory Governance in the SADC region. This Wednesday at 14:00 CAT. Some really excellent speakers https://t.co/KcrDqlnYdI Anticipatory Governance in Africa is a super interesting topic.

More good news! A waiver of vaccine patents seems in the pipeline.  But it’s not just the IP that matters, it is also access to manufacturing technology and specialized equipment. I really hope SA & Africa ramp up in that regard. It will take planning, commitment and resources.

Good news! The SA COVID-19 variant can be ‘tamed’. See thread below. It was the right call to pass on our 1st batch of AZ vaccine, and switch to Pfizer, but such a long wait!😫Please all SA people be careful - especially as we head into winter - we cannot afford a 3rd wave 😷

It looks like a Malaria vaccine may be in the pipeline. https://t.co/640OxRPkC6 That will have a huge impact on the African continent. Fingers crossed, it’s sooner rather than later, and can happen amidst the Covid-19 emergency.
@AnnetteMees Doing fine by being careful 💪😎 Missing you & London. Bubbly on me as & when we’re all vaccinated. 🤗

@AnnetteMees You’re so very lucky! In SA only some health care workers jabbed. Now hoping that Pfizer can get to some elderly before a (winter) 3rd wave starts. Only Pfizer & J&J work for our variant. Rich world hogging Pfizer. Imo side effects mean your immune systems kicks in - that’s good!

Here we go;👇 clear signal (evidence) of something that was forecast some time ago as an indicator of climate change. Now it’s real. What a tragedy. May it now serve as a signal for us to take other forecasted indicators more seriously and try to prevent them becoming a reality.
